fields.bio: Each Truman Chocolate is carefully designed to perfection - from the selection of unique and flavorful all-natural ingredients to the research and experimentation performed to discover the best possible combination of ingredients to optimize the flavor. All Truman Chocolates consist of beautiful shells made of white, dark, or milk chocolate with ganache interiors. These ganache blends of chocolate, cream, and a combination of ingredients make up sixteen original flavors of Truman Chocolates.
fields.name: Truman Chocolates

fields.bio:
Messina Hof Winery & Resort, a Texas vineyard established in 1977 by Paul and Merrill Bonarrigo, is rooted in the union of two family heritages. Winemaker Paul Bonarrigo’s family dates back seven generations to Messina, Sicily. Merrill’s family is from Hof, Germany.

As their many devoted enthusiasts can attest, it is their goal to share the good life with you. Stroll through the vineyard. Smell the roses. Sit by the waterfall. Relax with a glass of crisp Riesling or rich Shiraz. Indulge in fresh vineyard cuisine. Linger over candlelit conversation. Enjoy a quiet evening among friends or with the one you love. Messina Hof welcomes you on this journey and hopes that they may guide you to discovering the romance and tradition of Messina Hof.
fields.name: Messina Hof Winery and Resort

fields.bio: Established in 1836, the Republic offers steak, wine, and whiskey with a focus on the use of fine, locally grown foods and simple Texas cooking in an elegant setting.
fields.name: The Republic
fields.location: 701 University Drive East Suite 406, College Station TX

fields.bio:
Christopher's World Grille is a restored 100-year-old Texas ranch house.

It has received an Award of Excellence from Wine Spectator Magazine in both 2006 and 2007 for its wine list and has won numerous local awards for Best Fine Dining, Most Romantic Dining and Best Chef in the Brazos Valley consistently in its nine-year history.

It has been featured in Texas Monthly as "rapidly being recognized outside its city limits". The restaurant has also been bestowed with a Newman 10 Award, a locally prestigious business award given to ten businesses each year for sales growth.
fields.name: Christopher's World Grille

fields.bio:
The Wolf Pen Creek Amphitheater is located in the heart of Texas in College Station, home of Texas A&M University.  Serving the Southeast Texas Market Area, with a local population of approximately 150,000 people, the amphitheater's potential is unlimited with the University enrollment being stable at 43,000+ students.

Opening in 1993, Wolf Pen Creek has hosted over 250 events.  The facility has established a remarkable reputation for quality shows, clean beautiful grounds, and down-home hospitality to both performers and guests.

Artists who have performed at Wolf Pen Creek include Tim McGraw, Willie Nelson, Pat Green, Robert Earl Keen, Big Otis, The Marshall Tucker Band, Jerry Jeff Walker, Bo Diddley, and more.

The Starlight Music Series is an 8-10 event concert series that takes place each spring and summer.  All Starlight Music Series events are free to the public.

Wolf Pen Creek Amphitheater welcomes promoters and private renters, while also hosting its own in-house shows and festivals.  Capable of hosting crowds of over 7,500, the facility houses a professional staff and rental terms are very reasonable.
fields.name: Wolf Pen Creek Amphitheater

fields.bio: Located in Downtown Bryan’s Historic district, The Stafford was originally constructed in the early 1900’s as an opera house.  With the progression of time it evolved into a silent film theater.   To complete the circle, it has been re-opened as a live music venue with a whole different sound.  Patrons can enjoy a unique blend of history, comfort, industrialization and a large variety of new and established talent.
fields.name: The Stafford Main Street

fields.bio:
Eclectic coffee shop & bar in Downtown Bryan. Live music EVERY NIGHT. Full bar. Large Patio. Premium Coffees. Free wireless internet. Local Art.
Check us out Sunday 6pm-2am
Tuesday-Saturday 3pm-2am
J Goodin EVERY TUESDAY
Open MIC EVERY WEDNESDAY at 9pm
Poetry Open Mic EVERY SUNDAY at 9pm
REVOLUTION is an alternative to most bars in Bryan/College Station. We welcome everything involving culture and most things counter culture. We pride ourselves in consistently booking the highest quality music that you will hear in the area.
Revolution constantly strives to improve and diversify our community, frequenty hosting fundraisers for community groups.
fields.name: Revolution Cafe & Bar

fields.bio:
Square One Bistro has been serving guests in downtown Bryan for over twelve years. While its regular patrons have found their way to its doors without the aid of a storefront sign all this time, downtown is growing, and new owners Molly and Travis are ready to grow with it.

      With or without a sign at the front door, what keeps the regulars coming back? It could be Square One’s ever-evolving gallery of art or the eclectic time-worn tables, but it’s probably the freshly prepared fare with ingredients like mashed potatoes charged with Parmesan, homemade croutons and Caesar dressing and individually crafted cream sauces. Then again, it could be the oft-requested Bread Pudding, too.

      Unlike the twin cities’ many franchises and chain chophouses that run heavy on kitsch and light on authentic flavor, Square One offers more than just a place to dine. It offers a gustatory experience, one with real food, paired for savor and prepared for taste.

      Find your way to Square One and find a meal with local flavor—real flavor.
fields.name: Square One Bistro
fields.location: 211 W WM J Bryan Pkwy, Bryan TX 77803

fields.bio: Best Hamburgers in Town!  Live music and drink specials
fields.name: Fitzwilly's Bar and Grille

fields.bio:
Caffe Capri was opened on September 18, 1995 by rami cerone, Texas A&M class of 95 relying solely on money from credit card cash advances.  It was a bold move, especially since downtown was not yet established.  Thirteen years later however, this restaurant continues to grow and has won numerous awards such as 'best Italian' and the 'Aggie 100' fastest growing businesses in the world. 

The menu is a combination of recipes:  the left side of the menu consists of items that come directly from the Cerone family kitchen.  The right side is the result of Rami constantly experimenting with different ingredients - what you see are the recipes that actually worked.  The marinara sauce is a secret recipe from his father’s family.  So secret in fact, that until November of 1995, his father would come twice a week just to make 30 gallons of sauce (but not before chasing everyone out of the kitchen).  Thankfully however, business picked up and twice a week was no longer enough so Rami finally learned the recipe.  The open kitchen is there so you can see the food being prepared - we have nothing to hide.

      We strive to be green and environmentally friendly.  For example, we have switched from foam carryout containers to those that are recyclable & biodegradable.  We recycle all of our cardboard and glass daily.  We use recycled paper for our printing needs.  We are striving to become a zero-waste business.

      This building was originally a grocery store.  However, only the tin ceiling remains original - the rest has been restored.  The tables and columns are made of a stone called rose travertine that was taken from the interior of an old downtown Bryan building.  Upstairs, we offer a private banquet room that can seat up to 60 people.  The music, although different for an Italian restaurant, adds to the upbeat atmosphere and the unique decor. 

      We pride ourselves on our attentive and friendly customer service our staff wants Caffe Capri to become your favorite restaurant.  Our biggest compliment is when customers bring back friends.  Thank you for choosing us and we hope to exceed your expectations.
fields.name: Caffe Capri

fields.bio: Eccell Steakhouse, a flagship property of the EccellGroup of College Station, is an upscale steakhouse in a fashionable atmosphere. Several notable characteristics lend a metropolitan and lively feeling to this restaurant. But it really is all about the beef, isn’t it? The finest Midwestern Aged Beef, both USDA Prime and Certified Angus Beef (CAB TM), are prepared in a state of the art infrared broiler. Capable of temperatures of 1000 to 2500 degrees, the broiler imparts a texture and flavor not easily duplicated. The steaks are carefully prepared with Kosher Salt, fresh cracked pepper and finished with our in-house matre’d butter. The restaurant is meant to excite the diner’s senses and entertain the lounge patron. Our design, from the inside out, was done by awarded industry professionals and overseen by the ownership. The kitchen was designed by one of the most renowned restaurant consultants in Texas and our dining and bar by an architect regularly retained for upscale hotel and restaurant concepts nationwide. The feeling is more fashionable than classic. The warm ambience is accompanied by warm, friendly staff. Our hiring and training insists on the most professional standards, and it shows in our staff. Although they are trained in classic principle, they understand the people quotient and are here to serve you. Our bar area is lively and exciting. From live jazz and piano to our signature “Eye-Dropper” Martinis, there is action abound. Our daily ½ price menu with drink specials accommodates the happy hour patron. The later hours ramp up for an enjoyable evening. Our wine list includes a varied selection of about 150 choices with an inventory of 1800 bottles. Although our menu is predominately beef, the depth in variety of the menu commands a large pool of wine to choose from to fully enhance and complete the dining experience
fields.name: Eccell Steakhouse
fields.location: 980 University Drive East-University Towne Center, College Station TX

fields.bio:
Independence Coffee Co. is nestled in the hills of Washington County. Deep traditional roots reside here. Early settlers to this region of Texas were a tough, rugged and very persistent 'lot' that dealt with many hardships in their struggle to thrive here. From the settlement of Washington, where brave pioneering Texans signed the Texas Declaration of Independence from Mexico in an 'unfinished' frame building during the seige of the Alamo, to Chappell Hill, (the area's once thriving commerce center) which bounced back after yellow fever took nearly its entire population around 1867. In the county seat of Brenham, a devastating fire as well as strife brought on by the Civil War could not hinder its residents' will to make this area home.


Like the early settlers, Independence Coffee Co. is proud of this area's great heritage and we strive to 'mirror' its pioneering spirit with our determination to make our coffee company and roastery the best source of the highest quality coffee for our customers.
fields.name: Independence Coffee

fields.bio:
Having worked in food service almost twenty years, I have experience in virtually every position in a restaurant. I received formal training in Dallas, Texas, where I attended a culinary apprenticeship program. The program included class work and an internship. I count myself fortunate to have apprenticed at the renowned Crescent Court Hotel where I developed a desire for expert precision and professionalism in the kitchen. Now, as a Chef and restaurateur, I continue to self-educate and challenge myself through research and experimentation.

In 2002, I joined the Texas Chefs Association and shortly thereafter achieved Executive Chef Certification through the American Culinary Federation. In 2003, I received a Brazos Valley Chef of the year nomination, and in 2004 I was nominated and elected for both Chef of the year and Director of our local chapter. Representing the TCA, I participated in the annual Madisonville Mushroom Festival, giving demonstrations on the preparation of mushroom-based dishes and serving gourmet food. Opening my own restaurant is a culmination of desires, dreams, and skills. It provides me the freedom of self-expression and enables me to continue challenging myself in my career and life.

I enjoy inspiring future culinarians through cooking demonstrations at local schools and volunteering at community events. I hope to someday be a challenger on Iron Chef and to meet Alton Brown – a man I greatly admire.

My wife Tara and I serve on the local Young Life Committee. I am forever grateful for the blessings Christ has bestowed upon my family and me, and I pray that my life will continue to be filled with His passion and will.

I also want to say a special "thank you" to Kay Conlee as well as Gerald and Kelly Madden!
-Peter Madden
fields.name: Maddens Casual Gourmet

fields.bio: The inspiration for Café Eccell comes from the devotion to the use of fresh product, an atmosphere of casual sophistication, and the utilization of simple yet poised service principles. Although well known for our Pastry Chef’s dessert offerings, Café Eccell is much more. In College Station’s Old City Hall the Fresh Seafood is cleaned in-house daily, the wood burning pizza fire is built by hand, and the kitchen fires up with food that excites the senses. In addition to serving fresh seafood that is served within 24 hours of arrival, such as the Seared Chilean Sea Bass, Voo Doo Salmon, and Panko-Crusted Lump Cakes, there is a plentiful selection of fare such as the Famous 101 Church Chicken Salad, the Certified Angus Beef Steaks, and the Shrimp BLT. Café Eccell really is a true Grill and Fresh Seafood Bistro.
fields.name: Cafe Eccell

fields.bio: Veritas presents a unique blend of contemporary décor and related cosmopolitan ambience inviting you to sample the culinary creations of its executive chef, Tai Lee. Dramatic contrasts of light and color, emitting from the classically brilliant Shoenbeck crystals, reflecting against the striking Venetian plaster and hand-painted walls, create an elegant setting found only in the finest dining establishments. The extraordinary atmosphere takes fine dining in Bryan/College Station to an all-new level of excellence. Come experience the sense of excitement at Veritas destined to be a Brazos Valley Classic.
fields.name: Veritas Wine and Bistro
fields.location: 830 University Drive East Suite 400, College Station TX

fields.bio:
The City of Bryan Parks and Recreation Department is responsible for marketing and renting the Palace Theatre, as well as maintaining its annual calendar. Regular events available to the general public are scheduled at the theatre throughout the year.  These events may include various concerts, festivals, and shows.                         
Individuals or organizations may rent the facility for a fee. Such events may include private parties, dance recitals, or stage productions. The facility may be available for rent during weekdays, evenings, and weekends, seven days a week. The facility is closed on city-recognized holidays, unless other arrangements are made with staff. The Palace Theatre is shaded with seating for 400 people.     
User friendly rental options are available to the leasee, i.e. use of limited facility, use of full stage and dressing room, marquee, etc.  Actual rental is on a first-come, first-served basis with bookings accepted no more than one year in advance.
fields.name: The Palace Theater

fields.bio:
Reed Arena provides a first-class facility for entertainment, education and business needs of Texas A&M University as well as for the Bryan and College Station communities.  Possibilities are almost limitless in the Reed Arena with concert seating possible for expected audiences of 2,500 to 12,500. Large events include concerts, family entertainment, trade shows, student programs, Texas A&M University basketball games and commencement ceremonies.

That's just the beginning. Reed Arena provides an ideal location for a luncheon for 50 people, a large room for a festive wedding reception or perhaps a smaller room for a meeting, training program or other gathering.
fields.name: Reed Arena

fields.bio: Zapatos Cantina is a great outdoor venue for up and coming to established bands. Happy hour from 11am to 8pm daily. Booking is now handled through this myspace account or you can call Ashley at 979-450-3242. Calls will be taken from 3-7 Tues-Fri. Please do not call on game days. To inquire about all other subjects, please call the bar at 979 260 0662. Kitchen Schedule Spring '09 Monday 11-3 Tuesday 11-3 Wednesday 11-3 Thursday 11-10 Friday 11-10 Saturday 11-10 Sunday 11-3
fields.name: Zapatos Cantina

fields.bio: Live music, drink specials, and fun! Something for everyone at Schotzi's! Check out our new dance club upstairs at SKYY BAR!
fields.name: Schotzi's

fields.bio: The Arts Council of the Brazos Valley is a dynamic organization serving the arts and cultural needs of a large five county area in central Texas. The P. David Romei Arts Center houses the Texas Gallery that exhibits and sells works by Texas artists. The Arts Council is also responsible for the public art sculptures located throughout the Bryan - College Station community.
fields.name: P. David Romei Arts Center

fields.bio:
Julia and David, along with their longtime associate Dean Wile began the store in 1983 with the goal to create an environment that fosters creativity, honesty and quality.  That goal was rewarded in 1992 when they were extended membership into the American Gem Society. David Gardner’s is part of only 5% of jewelers, designers, appraisers and suppliers nationwide who have met the exacting standards of the organization. Standards that include a dedication to ethics, knowledge and consumer protection.

Staff members are encouraged to continue their education with opportunities from the American Gem Society, Gemological Institute of America, and various training seminars throughout the country.

Julia and David are committed to give back to the community that has generously supported their business.  They are proud supporters of the various community organizations such at the Boys & Girls Clubs of the Brazos Valley, American Cancer Society, MSC OPAS, Twin City Mission and numerous others.  

The “Aggie Spirit” is alive and well at David Gardner’s Jewelers.  Julia and David are ardent supporters of Texas A&M University.  They are frequent speaking guests in the College of Business and are sponsors of the Center for Retailing Studies. In 2006, David Gardner’s Jewelers begin a partnership with the athletic department and is the “Official Jeweler of Aggie Athetics.”
fields.name: David Gardner's Jewelers
fields.location: 911 University Drive East, College Station TX

fields.bio: The mission of the gallery is to create awareness of the local art of the Brazos Valley and to give all forms of art a stage to be enjoyed together. New shows are typically debuted monthly, when downtown businesses host “First Friday.” Each art opening is accompanied with a live music act and cuisine from the Village Cafe. First Friday is a great opportunity to come enjoy art, live music, and great food. Current shows can also be viewed Monday through Friday from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. and on weekends from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.
fields.name: art979 Gallery

fields.bio: TTC is excited about our 2008—2009 season, Mixing The Old With The New! Our new season includes six musical crowd-pleasers; just look at the titles on this page! This year will also feature a repeat of our Monster Bash Masquerade Ball, plus a holiday Children's Theatre Workshop! We fully anticipate performing for sell-out crowds due to the popularity of these shows, and the only way to absolutely guarantee your place in the audience is to buy your season tickets now!
fields.name: The Theatre Company of BCS

fields.bio:
The mission of The Children’s Museum of the Brazos Valleyis to provide a child-centered, hands-on, interactive environment for learning and discovery for children.
Hours of Operation:
Monday - Saturday:
10:00 AM - 5:00 PM
fields.name: The Children's Museum

fields.bio:
Nightlife - Business - Club Management
Just an Aggie alum trying to never work for the man!
fields.name: Paddock Lane

fields.bio:
Here at Village Café and Art979 Gallery, we would like to offer you what you seek to the best of our ability.  We hope to present a comfortable atmosphere and a pleasurable dining experience.  In order to achieve this, we will provide you with what we see as the highest quality available.  Between 80 and 90% of our ingredients are either “organic” or “natural”.

We are currently working with more than 15 local growers and businesses and are working towards using completely local products.  As we become more in tune with the growing seasons of the area, our menu will begin to rotate based on local availability.  This means the food you experience here is extremely fresh, healthy, tasty, and often picked the same day you eat it.  We refrain from using refined products, bleached flour, hydrogenated oils, or microwaves.  Everything is house-made and prepared in ways that maintain flavor and nutrients.

We are trying to minimize our footprint on the earth by recycling, reducing, conserving, and working to make a positive impact in the community.  With your help and patronage we will continue to grow the local economy and food systems.  Please let us know if you have any further ideas or suggestions.  Thank you for joining us, we hope you enjoy your visit.

Hours of Operation
NOW OPEN MONDAYS!!
Mon.-Fri. 7am to 5pm
Sat. and Sun. 10am to 5pm
fields.name: Village Cafe

fields.bio: Stagecenter is Bryan/College Station's premier community theater with a rich history of over 40 years. It is the only all-volunteer community theatre in the Brazos Valley and our doors remain open to all those who want to participate in the exciting and rewarding experience of live theatre.
fields.name: StageCenter Theater

fields.bio: t’s a world of excellent theatre in an historic, picturesque setting. Join us and we’ll take you on intriguing journeys to other times and places. From across the region, professional actors, directors, designers, and technicians come together to bring you fascinating stories and characters. Many of these artists are acclaimed in the Texas theatre community. Our historic building and scenic Brenham will take you back in time. We are in the Downtown Historic District, walking distance from fine dining, quaint shops and luxurious lodging. You’ll find this irresistible world just a short drive from Austin and Houston, amid rolling hills filled with lush landscapes. We hope you will join us this season for every turn in the road. You’ll be surprised and delighted with the world we have to share.
fields.name: Unity Theatre of Brenham

fields.bio: MSC OPAS at Texas A&M University presents professional productions of theatre, music and dance programs that enlighten, entertain and inspire audiences of the Brazos Valley. OPAS programs are supported entirely by revenue generated from ticket sales, membership dues and contributions. Past programs presented by MSC OPAS include Yo-Yo Ma, Van Cliburn, Itzhak Perlman, Les Miserables, Rent and the world premiere of the Bolshoi Ballet Grigorovich Ballet (for which MSC OPAS received international media coverage including a write-up in The New York Times).
fields.name: MSC Opas

fields.bio: Currently directed by Jess Wade, III, the Brazos Valley Chorale pursues its commitment to excellence in choral music of all types. Today the Brazos Valley Chorale provides discerning audiences in Bryan/College Station, TX with performances of great choral music at the highest standards. The 100-voice Chorale is known and respected for its difficult and ambitious repertoire of great choral masterworks and contemporary classics. The singers form a cross-section of the community, from college students to retirees.
fields.name: Brazos Valley Chorale

fields.bio: The Stark Galleries are open Tuesday through Friday from 9 am to 8 pm, and Saturday and Sunday from 12 pm to 6 pm. The Galleries are closed on Mondays and for University holidays. You can always call ahead to make sure that we are open at (979) 845-6081.
fields.name: J. Wayne Stark Gallery

fields.bio: Live music
fields.name: Texas Hall of Fame

fields.bio: The Navasota Theatre Alliance (aka the NTA) is a community theatre organization housed in the Sunny Furman Theater in Navasota, Texas. NTA's mission is to perform, sponsor and promote professional quality theatrical productions for the Brazos Valley. Theatrical Excellence in its 24th Year!
fields.name: Navasota Theatre Alliance

fields.bio: The Brazos Valley Symphony is a non-profit performing arts organization with the mission to maintain a symphony of high artistic standards, and to promote the musical arts for cultural and education purposes in the Brazos Valley.
fields.name: Brazos Valley Symphony Orchestra
fields.location: 909 Southwest Pkwy East Suite 200, College Station TX

fields.bio:
The Frame Gallery offers custom framing for diplomas, works of art, needlework, prints and posters, mirrors as well as creative shadowboxes for family mementos. Original works of art by more than 50 local and area artists are featured as well. 

Sarah, the shop dog and official greeter, and Greta Watkins, owner and local artist, invite you to stop by for a visit soon!
fields.name: The Frame Gallery

fields.bio:
“My mission is to leave an indelible positive mark on society and the environment through art, photography, literature, building design, music, and film. 
There are four factors necessary for the continuous development and cohesion of the human race: the first is education, the second is the understanding and appreciation of culture and heritage, the third is the protection of human rights and freedom, and the fourth is the protection of our environment and resources for future generations. As an artist, my focus is to make significant creations that promote these four factors. Art transcends all boundaries. A beautiful painting, image, or song can touch any human beings heart regardless of cultural boundaries and be a thread of peace and understanding.  
I personally sign and donate art prints to all scholarship and charitable fundraising events that promote and benefit the positive development of society. Simply fill out the donation form in Galleries and Contact Info or call us with your request.” 
-Benjamin Knox
fields.name: Benjamin Knox Gallery
fields.location: 405 University Drive East, College Station TX

fields.bio: real history-real paintings-real glass-real stories-real art
fields.name: MSC Forsyth Center Gallery

fields.bio: Mud Creek Pottery produces several lines of art pottery that are functionally utilitarian, while appealing to the aesthetic. Sonny currently works with Cone 6 Stoneware, Cone 11 Stoneware, Porcelain, and Raku Firing.
fields.name: Mud Creek Pottery

fields.bio: "For I know the plans I have for you, plans to prosper you and not to harm you, plans to give you hope and a future."  Jeremiah 29:11
fields.name: Joy Pottery

fields.bio:
When a movie-star dashing patisseur, experienced in Europe's finest kitchens, tells you with an inviting British accent that his company, COCOAMODA, makes the best chocolates in the world, you tend to take him at his word. When he goes on to say that he creates these delicacies in a state-of-the-art cafÃ© and chocolate factory that he designed himself - a former 19th century dry goods store - in Calvert, Texas, you know that something truly extraordinary is happening.
Calvert, a sleepy hamlet in western Robertson County that boasts a perfectly preserved historic downtown, once home to an opera house and the largest cotton gin in the world, is back on the map with world-class ganaches, confections and truffles, crafted by Ken Wilkinson - the creative genius behind COCOAMODA.
Wilkinson embodies a philosophy of pursuing excellence at all costs and refusing mediocrity in any shape or form. He oversees every aspect of the creation of COCOAMODA. A classically trained chef hailing from a family of carpenters, Wilkinson designed this ultra-modern operation - from the intricate woodwork to the retrofitted machinery salvaged from an old Pittsburgh chocolate factory. The historic building and kitchen reflect the COCOAMODA chocolates that are crafted thanks to the best of time-tested, traditional techniques in the service of modern, creative innovation.
COCOAMODA's chocolate creations will be made with the world's best couverture, or chocolate base, made by the French company Valrhona, where he recently met with 10 of the world's most renowned chocolatiers. Cost is no concern when it comes to sourcing the finest ingredients available: almonds from Spain, saffron and pistachios from Iran, hazelnuts from Oregon, Swiss frais de bois, and milk and cream from grass-fed Guernsey cows.
A trip to Calvert isn't just about tasting chocolate. Visitors to COCOAMODA can experience the chocolate-making process when they step into the chocolatier's factory. Just pass through a 19th century brick edifice into a reception room where windows offer a peak into melting vats of chocolate, cooling trays and conveyor belts where the delectable morsels are concocted and tastefully packaged - an area where the heat and humidity must be rigidly controlled to ensure the best quality. The finished product awaits you just across the street at COCOAMODA's restaurant and boutique - a Parisian style cafÃ© housed in a restored 1870's bank building.
While he spent the last five years meticulously planning every detail of COCOAMODA, Wilkinson has been preparing his entire career. His early success would make the plot of a great movie. Still a teenager, back in his native England after training in Switzerland, he apprenticed at a hotel restaurant one busy Friday night when the mercurial chef threw desserts against the wall and walked out, followed shortly after by the sous chef and the saucier. Showing his gift for alchemy that would later mark his chocolate creations, our boy Wilkinson saw the wonderful opportunity in a terrible situation. He stepped into the breech, holding the kitchen down through the weekend and for the next three weeks while the replacements were sought, and actually improved the food and service.
The legend spread through the local restaurant scene, and chefs began dropping by to check out this preternaturally talented teen, one of whom secured Wilkinson an apprenticeship in the Michelin-starred kitchen at the legendary Bahnhof Buffet in Lucerne, Switzerland. Working on ancient appliances under chefs trained in the style and discipline of the inventor of French cuisine, Escoffier, Wilkinson "took every kick and beating with a smile."
That Wilkinson, already a success in London, would submit himself to such harsh training techniques speaks to his relentless pursuit of excellence right to the very source. His talent led him to the most refined culinary art, chocolate making, and back in England he studied with the famous chocolatier Eric Berger, whose intricate techniques, kept under lock and key, would be lost to the world save for Wilkinson and Berger's own sons.
Meanwhile members of the royal family kept him busy catering lavish events, which he decorated with his filigreed chocolate sculptures. In the 1980's Wilkinson moved to Houston where he hosted Cable Cookery, a television show dedicated to making classical French cuisine accessible to everyday cooks. He married and started a family, and so it is in Texas that he fulfills his dream of creating the best chocolate experience in the world.
In recognition of how one man's vision is transforming the face of the historic downtown, the local Chamber of Commerce suggested calling Calvert the "Chocolate Capital of Texas and Birthplace of COCOAMODA." If the experience in Calvert is any indication, other major American cities will be clamoring for their own COCOAMODA boutiques. Not bad for a man with a dream who stumbled upon a little old ghost town with beautiful buildings.
Wilkinson offers his own motto, as colorful as his exciting chocolate concoctions: "Paris in Calvertâ€¦ why not?"
fields.name: CocoaModa
